mpc package

Submodules

mpc.linear_mpc module

class MPC(mpc_params: MPCProblem)[source]

Bases: object

MPC controller class for linear systems.

The MPC class is supposed to create a controller minimizing the following optimal control problem

\[\begin{split}&\min_{x,u} \sum_{t=0}^{N-1} (x_t^T Q x_t + u_t^T R u_t) + x_N^T Q_T x_N\\ &\text{s.t.} \\ &x_{t+1} = A x_t + B u_t \\ &H_u u_t \leq h_u \\ &H_x x_t \leq h_x \\ &H_y (C x_t + D u_t) \leq h_y \\ &x_0 = x_0\end{split}\]
compute(x0, *args, **kwargs) → tuple[ndarray, ndarray][source]

Compute the optimal control action for a given initial state.

Parameters:

x0 (np.ndarray) – The initial state.

Returns:

The optimal state and control trajectories.

Return type:

tuple

get_control_action(x0, *args, **kwargs)[source]

Get the first control action for a given initial state.

Parameters:

x0 (np.ndarray) – The initial state.

Returns:

The first control action.

Return type:

float

class SetPointTrackingMPC(mpc_params: MPCProblem)[source]

Bases: object

MPC controller class for set-point tracking of linear systems.

Main controller :

\[\begin{split}&\min_{x,u} sum_{t=0}^{N-1} (x_t - x_{ref})^T Q (x_t - x_{ref}) + (u_t - u_{ref})^T R (u_t - u_{ref})\\ &s.t.\\ &x_{t+1} = A x_t + B u_t + B_d d_t\\ &H_u u_t \leq h_u \\ &H_x x_t \leq h_x \\ &H_y (C x_t + D u_t) \leq h_y \\ &x_0 = x_0\end{split}\]
compute(x0)[source]
get_control_action(x0: ndarray, reference: ndarray, disturbance: ndarray | None = None, **kwargs)[source]

Compute the control action for a given state, reference, and optional disturbance.

set_disturbance(disturbance: ndarray)[source]

Set the disturbance parameter if disturbances are defined (known disturbance entering the model).

Parameters:

disturbance (np.ndarray) – The disturbance.

set_reference(reference: ndarray)[source]

Set the reference for tracking.

Parameters:

reference (np.ndarray) – The reference trajectory.

class TimedMPC(mpc_params: MPCProblem)[source]

Bases: SetPointTrackingMPC

MPC controller class for set-point tracking of linear systems.

Main controller :

\[\begin{split}&\min_{x,u} sum_{t=0}^{N-1} (x_t - x_{ref})^T Q (x_t - x_{ref}) + (u_t - u_{ref})^T R (u_t - u_{ref})\\ &s.t.\\ &x_{t+1} = A x_t + B u_t + B_d d_t\\ &H_u u_t \leq h_u \\ &H_x x_t \leq h_x \\ &H_y (C x_t + D u_t) \leq h_y \\ &x_0 = x_0\end{split}\]

class SetPointTrackingNMPC(mpc_params: MPCProblem)[source]

Bases: object

Class for set-point output tracking Nonlinear MPC (NMPC)

Problem formulation :

min_{x,u} sum_{k=0}^{N-1} (x_k - x_ref)^T Q (x_k - x_ref) + (u_k - u_ref)^T R (u_k - u_ref)

s.t.

x_{k+1} = f(x_k, u_k, d_k) y_k = g(x_k, u_k, d_k) u_k = -L @ (x_k - x_ref) + u_ref + v_k

u_k in U, x_k in X, y_k in Y x_0 = x

where : x is the state, u is the control input, d is the disturbance, y is the output f, g are the system dynamics and output functions, respectively.

The control input is assumed to be of the form u_k = -L(x_k - x_ref) + u_ref + v_k where L is a reference the feedback gain (for example an LQR computer over the linearised dynamics), x_ref is the reference state, u_ref is the reference input, and v_k is the control deviation term (which is optimised by the NMPC). By default L = 0 byt it but it could be set to an LQR controller for example.

The system takes a reference output point y_ref from which a state and input u_ref,x_ref are computed such that f(x_ref, u_ref, d) = 0 and g(x_ref, u_ref, d) = y_ref. The solution with minimum norm control input is selected among all the possible solutions.

The disturbance acting on the system is a parameter of the optimization.

compute_predicted_optimal_controls(x0: ndarray, yref: ndarray, d: ndarray | None = None)[source]

Compute the optimal control and state trajectories for the given initial state.

Parameters:

  • x0 (np.array) – Initial state.

  • yref (np.array) – Reference output.

  • d (np.array) – Disturbance (optional).

Returns:

Optimal control trajectory and optimal state trajectory.

Return type:

(np.array, np.array)

get_control_action(x: ndarray, y_ref: ndarray, d: ndarray | None = None)[source]

MPC controller that plans optimal controls and states over the prediction horizon and returns the first control action in the predicted optimal sequence.

Parameters:

  • x (np.array) – Current state.

  • y_ref (np.array) – Reference output.

  • d (np.array, optional) – Disturbance (optional).

Returns:

The first control action in the predicted optimal sequence.

Return type:

np.array

mpc.parameters module

class MPCProblem(system: LinearSystem | NonlinearSystem, horizon: int, Q: ndarray, R: ndarray, QT: ndarray | None = None, global_penalty_weight: float = 1.0, solver: str | None = None, slack_penalty: str = 'SQUARE')[source]

Bases: object

Base class to define all the parameters for the MPC controller.

add_dual_mode(horizon: int, controller: ndarray)[source]

Add a dual mode to the MPC with an optional controller and horizon.

For a linear system you will typically put an LQR controller here.

Parameters:

  • dual_mode_horizon (int) – The horizon for the dual mode.

  • controller (numpy.ndarray) – The controller for the dual mode.

add_general_input_constraints(Hu: ndarray, bu: ndarray, is_hard: bool = True, penalty_weight: int = 1)[source]

Add general input constraints of the form Hu * u <= bu.

add_general_output_constraints(Hy: ndarray, by: ndarray, is_hard: bool = True, penalty_weight: int = 1)[source]

Add general output constraints of the form Hy * y <= by.

add_general_state_constraints(Hx: ndarray, bx: ndarray, is_hard: bool = True, penalty_weight: int = 1)[source]

Add general state constraints of the form Hx * x <= bx.

add_general_state_time_constraints(Hx: ndarray, bx: ndarray, start_time: float, end_time: float, is_hard: bool = True, penalty_weight: int = 1)[source]

Add general time state constraints of the form A[x,t] <= bx.

add_input_bound_constraint(limits: tuple | float, input_index: int | None = None, is_hard: bool = True, penalty_weight: float = 1.0)[source]

Adds input bounds constraints. The constraints can be symmetric or asymmetric based on limits.

Parameters:

  • limits (float or tuple) – If a single float, the bounds are symmetric: -limits <= u_t <= limits. If a tuple (lb, ub), the bounds are asymmetric: lb <= u_t <= ub.

  • input_index (int | None) – If None, apply the constraints to all inputs uniformly. If an int, apply the constraint to a specific input.

  • is_hard (bool) – Whether the constraint is hard or soft.

  • penalty_weight (float) – The penalty weight for soft constraints.

add_input_magnitude_constraint(limit: float, input_index: int | None = None, is_hard: bool = True, penalty_weight: float = 1.0)[source]

Add input magnitude constraint: -limit <= u <= limit.

Parameters:

  • limit (float) – The magnitude limit for the input.

  • input_index (int | None) – The index of the input to apply the constraint to. If None, apply to all inputs.

  • is_hard (bool) – Whether the constraint is hard or soft.

  • penalty_weight (float) – The penalty weight for soft constraints.

add_output_bound_constraint(limits: tuple | float, output_index: int | None = None, is_hard: bool = True, penalty_weight: float = 1.0)[source]

Adds output bounds constraints. The constraints can be symmetric or asymmetric based on limits.

Parameters:

  • limits – If a single float, the bounds are symmetric: -limits <= y_t <= limits. If a tuple (lb, ub), the bounds are asymmetric: lb <= y_t <= ub.

  • output_index (int | None) – If None, apply the constraints to all outputs uniformly. If an int, apply the constraint to a specific output.

  • is_hard (bool) – Whether the constraint is hard or soft.

  • penalty_weight (float) – The penalty weight for soft constraints.

add_output_magnitude_constraint(limit: float, output_index: int | None = None, is_hard: bool = True, penalty_weight: float = 1.0)[source]

Add magnitude constraint on a specific output: -limit <= y[output_index] <= limit.

add_reference_controller(controller: ndarray)[source]

Add a reference controller to the MPC.

Parameters:

controller (numpy.ndarray) – The reference controller for the MPC.

add_state_bound_constraint(limits: tuple | float, state_index: int | None = None, is_hard: bool = True, penalty_weight: float = 1.0)[source]

Adds state bounds constraints. The constraints can be symmetric or asymmetric based on limits.

Parameters:

  • limits (float or tuple) – If a single float, the bounds are symmetric: -limits <= x_t <= limits. If a tuple (lb, ub), the bounds are asymmetric: lb <= x_t <= ub.

  • state_index (int | None) – If None, apply the constraints to all states uniformly. If an int, apply the constraint to a specific state.

  • is_hard (bool) – Whether the constraint is hard or soft.

  • penalty_weight (float) – The penalty weight for soft constraints.

add_state_magnitude_constraint(limit: float, state_index: int | None = None, is_hard: bool = True, penalty_weight: float = 1.0)[source]

Add state magnitude constraint: -limit <= x[state_index] <= limit.

add_terminal_ingredients(controller: ndarray | None = None)[source]

Add terminal ingredients using a controller (defaults to LQR).

check_offsetfree_conditions()[source]

Check the conditions for offset-free MPC.

reach_refererence_at_steady_state(option: bool = True)[source]

Set the option to reach the reference at steady state or let the reference be reached from any state.

Parameters:

option (bool) – If True, the reference is reached at steady state. If False, the reference can be reached from any state.

soften_tracking_constraint(penalty_weight: float = 1.0)[source]

Enable softening of the tracking constraint with the specified penalty weight.

class SetPointTrackingNMPC(mpc_params: MPCProblem)[source]

Bases: object

Class for set-point output tracking Nonlinear MPC (NMPC)

Problem formulation :

min_{x,u} sum_{k=0}^{N-1} (x_k - x_ref)^T Q (x_k - x_ref) + (u_k - u_ref)^T R (u_k - u_ref)

s.t.

x_{k+1} = f(x_k, u_k, d_k) y_k = g(x_k, u_k, d_k) u_k = -L @ (x_k - x_ref) + u_ref + v_k

u_k in U, x_k in X, y_k in Y x_0 = x

where : x is the state, u is the control input, d is the disturbance, y is the output f, g are the system dynamics and output functions, respectively.

The control input is assumed to be of the form u_k = -L(x_k - x_ref) + u_ref + v_k where L is a reference the feedback gain (for example an LQR computer over the linearised dynamics), x_ref is the reference state, u_ref is the reference input, and v_k is the control deviation term (which is optimised by the NMPC). By default L = 0 byt it but it could be set to an LQR controller for example.

The system takes a reference output point y_ref from which a state and input u_ref,x_ref are computed such that f(x_ref, u_ref, d) = 0 and g(x_ref, u_ref, d) = y_ref. The solution with minimum norm control input is selected among all the possible solutions.

The disturbance acting on the system is a parameter of the optimization.
